sen.j: 鷹司 政熙（たかつかさ まさひろ 宝暦11年4月10日（1761年5月14日） - 天保11年2月7日（1841年3月29日））は、江戸時代中期の公家。
sen.e: Masahiro TAKATSUKASA (May 14, 1761 - March 29, 1841) was a member of court nobles in the mid Edo period.
Masahiro TAKATSUKASA (May 14, 1761 - March 29, 1841) was a member of court nobles during the mid Edo period.
Masahiro TAKATSUKASA (May 14, 1761 - March 29, 1841) was a member of court nobles during the mid Edo period.
He was Toshi choja (head of the Fujiwara clan).
He was Toshi choja (head of the Fujiwara clan).
He was Toshi choja (head of the Fujiwara clan).
He was Kanpaku (chief adviser to the Emperor), ranked at Juichii (Junior First Rank).
He was Kanpaku (chief adviser to the Emperor), ranked at Juichii (Junior First Rank).
He was Kanpaku (chief adviser to the Emperor), ranked at Juichii (Junior First Rank).
Family Record
Family Record
Family Record

sen.j: 父は閑院宮直仁親王第4王子で、鷹司基輝の養子となり藤原姓鷹司家を継承した鷹司輔平。
sen.e: His father was Sukehira TAKATSUKASA, who was the 4th son of Imperial Prince Kaninnomiya Naohito, and was later adopted by Mototeru TAKATSUKASA and took over the Takatsukasa Family of Fujiwara cognomen

His father was Sukehira TAKATSUKASA, who was the 4th son of Imperial Prince Kaninnomiya Naohito, and was later adopted by Mototeru TAKATSUKASA and took over the Takatsukasa Family of Fujiwara cognomen

His father was Sukehira TAKATSUKASA, who was the 4th son of Imperial Prince Kaninnomiya Naohito, and was later adopted by Mototeru TAKATSUKASA and took over the Takatsukasa family of Fujiwara cognomen.
sen.cmt: ｆamilyに訂正しました。ピリオド補足。

sen.j: 母は長州藩藩主、毛利重就の娘、文子（惟保局）。
sen.e: His mother Fumiko (Iho no tsubone), who was a daugher of Shigetaka MORI, the lord of the Choshu domain.
His mother Fumiko (Iho no tsubone), was the daugher of Shigetaka MORI, the lord of the Choshu domain.
His mother Fumiko (Iho no tsubone), was the daughter of Shigetaka MORI, the lord of the Choshu domain.

sen.j: 兄妹に徳大寺実堅、昌子（伏見宮邦頼親王妃）、富子（有栖川宮織仁親王妃）、興姫（仙台藩八代藩主伊達斉村室）。
sen.e: Sanemi Tokudaiji was his brother, and Masako (the wife of Fushiminomiya Imperial Prince Kuniyori), Tomiko (the wife of Arisugawanomiya Imperial Prince Orihito) and Oki hime (the wife of Narimura DATE, who was the 8th lord of the Sendai domain) were his sisters.

Sanemi Tokudaiji was his brother, and Masako (the wife of Fushiminomiya Imperial Prince Kuniyori), Tomiko (the wife of Arisugawanomiya Imperial Prince Orihito) and Oki hime (the wife of Narimura DATE, who was the 8th lord of the Sendai domain) were his sisters.

Sanemi Tokudaiji was his brother, and Masako (the wife of Imperial Prince Fushiminomiya Kuniyori), Tomiko (the wife of Imperial Prince Arisugawanomiya Orihito) and Oki hime (the wife of Narimura DATE, who was the 8th lord of the Sendai domain) were his sisters.
sen.cmt: Imperial Prince Fushiminomiya Kuniyori、Imperial Prince Arisugawanomiya Orihitoに訂正しました。

sen.j: 正室は徳島藩十代藩主蜂須賀重喜の娘、蜂須賀儀子。
sen.e: His lawful wife was Noriko HACHISUKA, who was a daughter of Shigeyoshi HACHISUKA, the 10th lord of the Tokushima domain.
His lawful wife was Noriko HACHISUKA, who was a daughter of Shigeyoshi HACHISUKA, the 10th lord of the Tokushima domain.
His lawful wife was Noriko HACHISUKA, who was a daughter of Shigeyoshi HACHISUKA, the 10th lord of the Tokushima domain.

sen.j: 側室に豊岡斐子と井上梅。
sen.e: Haishi TOYOOKA and Ume INOUE were his concubines.
sen.cmt: 井上梅の読み方の確認が取れませんでした。

Haishi TOYOOKA and Ume INOUE were his concubines.

sen.j: 明和7年（1770年）権大納言、正三位
sen.e: In 1770, he became Gon Dainagon (provisional major counselor), ranked at Shosanmi (Senior Third Rank).
In 1770, he became Gon Dainagon (provisional major counselor), ranked at Shosanmi (Senior Third Rank).

In 1791, he became Sadaijin (Minister of the left).
In 1795, he became Uji no choja (the head of the clan), and also became Kanpaku (chief adviser to the Emperor).

In 1800, he was ranked Jusangu (honorary rank next to the three Empresses: Great Empress Dowager, Empress Dowager, and Empress).
sen.cmt: (honorary rank next to the three Empresses: Great Empress Dowager, Empress Dowager, and Empress)補足

sen.e: In 1814, he left the post of Kanpaku.
In 1814, he left the post of Kanpaku.
In 1814, he left the post of Kanpaku.

sen.j: 文政6年（1823年）出家（法名楽山）
sen.e: In 1823, he entered into priesthood (the homyo (a name given to a person who enters the Buddhist priesthood) was Rakusan).
sen.cmt: 楽山の読み方の確認が取れませんでした。
